A **healthstone** (in SLASH'EM) is a [gray stone](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone") that modifies a player's heal rate. [Blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") or [uncursed](/wiki/Uncursed "Uncursed") healthstones increase it, while [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") healthstones decrease it.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Healing mechanics](#Healing_mechanics)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [4 Credits](#Credits)

## Generation

Unfortunately, healthstones are always generated cursed. Players picking up an unknown gray stone may want to [bag](/wiki/Bag "Bag") it until they can curse-test it. A cursed gray stone that is not a [loadstone](/wiki/Loadstone "Loadstone") is almost always a healthstone: this can be useful as a way to pseudo-identify them.

Healthstones can also be created with a 1 in 2 chance by [upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading_objects "Upgrading objects") [flint stones](/wiki/Flint_stone "Flint stone").

## Healing mechanics

Unlike luckstones, healthstones are cumulative - two blessed healthstones are better than one. To be precise, you have a [health](/wiki/Health "Health") recovery bonus which is 2 for each blessed healthstone in your main inventory, plus 1 for each uncursed healthstone, minus 2 for each cursed healthstone. This bonus is added to your [level](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level") and [constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") when calculating how fast or how much you [heal](/wiki/HP#Hit_point_regeneration "HP"), i.e. if you carry 2 blessed healthstones at level 1 you will regenerate every 7th turn (as at level 5) instead of every 15th, and at level 29 you will regenerate 1d24 HP instead of 1d20 every 3 turns (provided your constitution is 20).

## Strategy

Healthstones are most effective at lower experience levels. In the examples above with two blessed healthstones, the level 1 character is healing over twice as quickly as they usually would, while the level 29 character is healing a mere 20% faster than normal. High-level characters should consider whether the [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight") of a large stack of healthstones might instead be better used for items that can kill monsters quickly, such as [wands of death](/wiki/Wand_of_death "Wand of death"), as well as for emergency healing items such as blessed [tins](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of [nurse](/wiki/Nurse "Nurse") meat or [potions of full healing](/wiki/Potion_of_full_healing "Potion of full healing").

## Credits

Mechanics adapted from a [spoiler](https://web.archive.org/web/20090409061754/http://www.statslab.cam.ac.uk/~eva/slashem/stones.html) by Eva Myers.
